claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadens the MHC-I peptidome and tumor antigen display.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.

claims.claim: Combined intratumoral mRNA vaccination and checkpoint blockade improves survival in human metastatic patients.

evidence.quote: Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.claim: The sensitization effect depends on type I interferon signaling.

evidence.quote: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: Lipid particle controls without mRNA do not produce tumor sensitization to immune checkpoint inhibitors.

evidence.quote: Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.
The paper investigates whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.

claims.caveat: Prospective randomized studies are required before clinical protocol changes are justified.
